author: By Sopan Deb
title: These Classic Characters Are Losing Copyright Protection. They May Never Be the Same.
description: What could happen to the original version of Mickey Mouse and others after they entered the public domain on Jan. 1? Hint: think Winnie the Pooh wielding a sledgehammer.
content: If you’re the creative type and you’re struggling to come up with your next idea, do not fear: some big works, including the original version of Mickey Mouse, are entering the public domain on Jan. 1 in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: PGA Tour and Saudi-Backed LIV Extend Deadline to Finalize Deal
description: The tentative deal for the men’s golf circuits to join forces had a Dec. 31 deadline, but significant questions remained.
content: When the PGA Tour and the upstart LIV Golf league, which is bankrolled by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, announced their groundbreaking deal in June for the men’s golf circuits to join forces, they left most details unanswered and set a Dec. 31 deadline to figure them out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Trump Cacophony Hits Differently This Time
description: Even if he never wins a general election again, he retains his hold. The endurance of that power is incredible.
content: When was the last time you listened to Donald Trump speak at length? There’s a qualitative way to think about this question, about the substance of what he’s saying: He is still talking — perhaps more than people realize — about how the last election was stolen from him, and he treats the 2020 election as a Year Zero event that has ruined the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: How Telling Stories to My Daughter Got Me Through the Darkest Times
description: Amid an unhinged far-right presidency and a devastating pandemic, it was a lifeline.
content: I was nursing a 4-month-old baby when Jair Bolsonaro won Brazil’s presidential election in 2018. It was a disaster, and I knew it right away. My daughter — let’s call her Potato — kept on sucking while I shed tears over her head. Then I changed her into a rainbow onesie to indicate my displeasure with our future president, who once said he was “proud to be homophobic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: A New Year’s Energy Boost
description: This year, we’re going to feel less tired.
content: It’s the first day of the year. Raise your hand if you could use more energy! That’s everybody, then?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and Kelley Manley
title: Police Officers Are Charged With Crimes, but Are Juries Convicting?
description: Since the death of George Floyd, a national movement promised sweeping justice reform. So far, police prosecutions have resulted in a mixed bag of convictions, acquittals and a mistrial.
content: A few days before Christmas, a jury in Washington cleared three Tacoma police officers of criminal charges in the death of Manuel “Manny” Ellis, a 33-year-old Black man who died in police custody in 2020 after pleading that he could not breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Powerful Earthquake Hits Japan, and Officials Warn of Aftershocks
description: There were reports of collapsed buildings and people being trapped underneath them. The quake disrupted electricity and phone service, and initially raised fears of a tsunami.
content: A powerful earthquake struck western Japan on Monday, triggering tsunami warnings and evacuation orders, trapping people under collapsed buildings and disrupting electricity and mobile phone services in Ishikawa Prefecture, the epicenter of the quake, the Japanese authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Vivek Shankar
title: U.S. Helicopters Sink 3 Houthi Boats in Red Sea, Pentagon Says
description: Iranian-backed Houthi gunmen from Yemen had fired on American helicopters responding to an attack on a commercial ship, American officials said.
content: A clash between Iranian-backed Houthi fighters who were attacking a commercial freighter and U.S. Navy helicopters responding to the ship’s distress call ended on Sunday morning with the killing of all the crew members on three Houthi boats, the Pentagon said, a sharp escalation of violence at a moment when the White House is considering direct strikes on Iran’s proxies in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Met’s New ‘Carmen’ Trades Castanets for Cutoffs
description: Starring a magnetic Aigul Akhmetshina, Carrie Cracknell’s lethargic staging updates Bizet’s opera to present-day America.
content: The Metropolitan Opera says its new production of “Carmen” aims at “reinvigorating the classic story.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: New State Laws on Hot-Button Issues Take Effect Today
description: Many state laws take effect on the first day of 2024, including new rules on gun safety, a ban on diversity programs and a curb on telemarketing calls.
content: A spate of new state laws, including on guns, minimum wage and gender transition care, went into effect as the calendar flipped to 2024. Perhaps the most significant change bans programs that promote diversity, equity and inclusion at publicly funded colleges and universities in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: The Well Team Knows You’re Tired. And They’re Here to Help.
description: The Well desk’s energy challenge is the product of months of research and test runs with friends and family.
content: When around a dozen reporters and editors on The New York Times’s Well desk sat around a long table in a conference room in July to brainstorm ideas for a challenge readers could complete to jump-start their 2024, a variety of suggestions were thrown out: How to live a more joyful life. A week’s worth of decluttering exercises. A relationship challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: 5 Killed in Queens Car Crash on New Year’s Day
description: The accident occurred on the Cross Island Parkway, along a part known for its dangerous curve, residents said.
content: Just hours into the New Year on Monday, five people were killed in a two-car crash that involved an overturned vehicle in northern Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri
title: How to Start the New Year? Keep the Sea Goddess Happy.
description: Followers of Afro-Brazilian religions have been displaced by New Year’s revelers. But they still find ways to make their offerings to the ocean.
content: Each New Year’s Eve, more than two million revelers — twice as many as typically fill Times Square — dress in white and pack Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro to watch a 15-minute midnight fireworks extravaganza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Friction between the U.S. and Israel.
content: No other episode in the past half-century has tested the ties between the U.S. and Israel so significantly as the current war in Gaza. President Biden’s initial resolve to stand by Israel has given way to frustrating phone calls, sharp public comments and exhausting marathon meetings as the relationship has grown fraught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: In Quake-Scarred Japan, 2011 Fukushima Disaster Still Looms Large
description: As another major quake struck Japan, the country was still reckoning with the nuclear crisis triggered by the 8.9-magnitude earthquake and a tsunami of 13 years ago.
content: As Japan assesses the damage from Monday’s major earthquake, it is still reckoning with the devastating nuclear crisis triggered by an quake nearly 13 years ago, one that placed the name of Fukushima on par with Chernobyl’s and traumatized the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Mychal Threets Wants Everyone to Experience ‘Library Joy’
description: The 33-year-old librarian from California has become popular on TikTok and Instagram with his upbeat take on libraries.
content: However relevant the stereotypical, silence-enforcing librarian remains in the popular imagination, Mychal Threets wants to dispel any lingering notion of the library as a dry, humorless place, lorded over by rigid pedants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Raises Concerns About Church in Nicaragua
description: Speaking at his traditional New Year’s Day message, Francis highlighted the arrests and expulsion of clergy.
content: Pope Francis used his New Year’s Day address to highlight concern over the worsening situation of the Roman Catholic Church in Nicaragua as a result of a protracted crackdown by the government of President Daniel Ortega, which has detained clerics, expelled missionaries, closed Catholic radio stations and limited religious celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’ and the Golden Globes
description: The competition show featuring drag queens comes back for a 16th season. The annual award show airs on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 1-7. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Michael Levenson
title: Driver Crashes Into Manhattan Sidewalk, Injuring Several People
description: The motorist struck police cars and a food truck in Midtown early Monday morning. Victims were taken to local hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries, officials said.
content: At least 10 people were injured early Monday morning in Midtown Manhattan when the driver of a black sedan crashed into the sidewalk, striking police cars and a food truck, according to the New York City Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack, Gaya Gupta and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: Half of Gazans Are at Risk of Starving, U.N. Warns
description: More than 90 percent of Palestinians in the territory say they have regularly gone without food for a whole day, according to the United Nations.
content: Walaa Zaiter’s four children have been hungry for weeks, but she can barely find them food.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Gaza Mayor’s View of the Conflict
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about the war’s toll in Gaza. Also: Western businesses in Russia; abortion pill case; dogs and social media.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In a Jewish-Arab School, an Oasis From Division but Not From Deep Fears
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 1, 2024.
content: “It feels fun, a religious Jew being friends with an Arab.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dashka Slater
title: How Do You Respond to a Young Person Upset by Racist Jokes at School?
description: When you talk to students about social media radicalization, racism and bullying, you learn how desperate they are for some guidance.
content: The sixth-grade boy who raised his hand was wiry and small. “People at my school make racist jokes,” he said, when I called on him. His voice had yet to change. “How do I get them to stop?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: Chill in the Housing Market Seeps Into Other Industries
description: The slowdown in the residential real estate market, a crucial cog in the American economy, is threatening sectors like home improvement and storage.
content: John Matheson, a home inspector in Alameda, Calif., kept busy during the pandemic when the housing market was red hot. But as interest rates started to rise about halfway through 2022, he noticed that his workload began to drop. Last year, the number of jobs plummeted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump’s Most Ambitious Argument in His Bid for ‘Absolute Immunity’
description: The former president says his acquittal by the Senate in his second impeachment trial, for inciting insurrection, bars any prosecution on similar grounds.
content: There is almost nothing in the words of the Constitution that even begins to support former President Donald J. Trump’s boldest defense against charges that he plotted to overturn the 2020 election: that he is absolutely immune from prosecution for actions he took while in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: What Will Life Be Like in 2024?
description: Here are 12 guesses.
content: A new year brings new beginnings. For the Styles Desk, it also comes with an old pastime: Predicting the fashion and lifestyle trends that may bubble up in the months ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Want to Feel, Intellectually, Like Someone Is Rotating Your Tires?
description: This bracing anthology of Christopher Hitchens’s work for The London Review of Books is just the ticket.
content: There was a period in the late 1990s or thereabouts when Christopher Hitchens’s byline was, or seemed to be, stamped in every respectable magazine and newspaper published in English. The Nation had his biweekly political columns. The London Review of Books and Newsday (where he wrote weekly) had the bulk of his book reviews. He loitered in Condé Nast Traveler and The New Statesman and the TLS and The Atlantic and The New York Times Book Review and Slate and The New York Review of Books as if they were dive bars. Vanity Fair, where he had a monthly column, had the good sense to simply point him at things. The American South, for example. Or his own Brazilian bikini waxing. And his own waterboarding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fu and Rich Barbieri
title: China Auto Giant BYD Sells More Electric Vehicles Than Ever
description: Sales by BYD, the country’s dominant automaker, topped 3 million last year, including 1.6 million fully battery-powered cars. It’s a sign of China’s rapid growth in EVs.
content: The Chinese corporate giant BYD said Monday that it sold three million battery-powered cars in 2023, its most ever, capping a turbulent year for China’s electric vehicle industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Camille Baker and Sean Piccoli
title: In Times Square, Hundreds of Thousands Ring In 2024
description: New Year’s celebrations took place as protesters against the Israel-Hamas war staged demonstrations in Midtown Manhattan.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people crowded into Times Square on Sunday night to ring in the New Year, amid heightened security and scattered demonstrations in Midtown Manhattan over the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter, Alissa Wilkinson, Mike Hale, Salamishah Tillet, Jesse Green, Maya Phillips, Jason Zinoman, Margaret Lyons, Zachary Woolfe and Jon Pareles
title: What Our Critics Are Looking Forward to in 2024
description: “Mad Max” gets a prequel, “The Wiz” returns to Broadway and Larry David gets another crack at a series finale.
content: Early in 1969, the Metropolitan Museum sparked an uproar with an exhibition called “Harlem on My Mind: Cultural Capital of Black America, 1900-1968.” Although conceived as the museum’s first big-ticket acknowledgment of African American creativity, it included no visual art beyond documentary photomurals. Black artists, many working in Harlem just blocks north of the museum, angrily picketed the show, denouncing it as evidence of art world racism writ large.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: America Ferrera and the ‘Barbie’ Monologue We All Talked About
description: The key moment in the smash hit went through many revisions: “We ended in tears. It ended in laughter, it got big, it got small.”
content: Listing some of the many perils of womanhood in a still patriarchal society, the monologue that the actress America Ferrera delivers in “Barbie” with the intensity of a rallying cry, became one of the most talked-about movie moments of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Joe Buglewicz
title: Can New Haven’s Legendary Pizza Joints Play on the National Stage?
description: The city has long been known as a pizza town. Now other places seem to be trying to cash in on the hype.
content: For generations, New Haven has been a pizza town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Day 1: A 5-Minute Trick for More Energy
description: Today’s challenge involves a little daytime rest.
content: To kick off our 6-Day Energy Challenge, we’re focusing on daytime rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: That Numbness You’re Feeling? There’s a Word for It.
description: Feeling other people’s pain is not the best way to help them — or yourself.
content: In mid-October, a few days after the attack on Israel, a friend sent me a text from a rabbi. She said she couldn’t look away from the horror on the news but felt completely numb. She was struggling to feel even the tiniest bit useful: “What can I even do?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Eric Schmitt
title: Israel Says It Will Pull Several Brigades From Gaza Strip
description: Analysts say the announcement could signal a shift to the more limited and targeted war against Hamas that the United States has been urging.
content: The Israeli military said on Monday that it would begin withdrawing several thousand troops from the Gaza Strip at least temporarily, in what was  the most significant publicly announced reduction since the war with Hamas began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel’s Top Court Strikes Down Move to Curb Its Powers
description: The Supreme Court, by the narrowest of margins, rejected a law pushed by Netanyahu allies that limited its authority to review government decisions.
content: Israel’s Supreme Court on Monday struck down a law limiting its own powers, a momentous step in the legal and political crisis that gripped the country before the war with Hamas, and pitted the court against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Kellen Browning
title: Trump Team, Burned in 2016, Looks to Close Out Iowa
description: The former president is leading by impressive margins in the state, but his campaign wants to make sure his supporters turn out.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump campaigned in Iowa in the fall, he projected the utmost confidence. He told his supporters during speeches that his advisers had constantly warned him not to take the state for granted. Buoyed by his dominance in state polls, Mr. Trump insisted he had no reason to worry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor Revival cottage in Carmel, an equestrian compound in the San Fernando Valley once owned by Patrick Swayze and a waterfront house in Huntington Beach.
content: This home, which received a Carmel Heritage Award in 2004, was built to resemble the older storybook cottages for which the city is known. It is a few blocks from Carmel Plaza, an outdoor dining and shopping hub, and within walking distance of a number of restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: It’s 2024. Here Are the New Laws That New Yorkers Should Know About.
description: Legislation touching on nearly every aspect of life in the state, including wages, health care and education, is going into effect in the coming months.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul signed roughly 900 bills in 2023. Those laws — many of which are scheduled to take effect in the new year — touch nearly every aspect of New Yorkers’ lives. There are measures recognizing additional school holidays (the Lunar New Year and Diwali), and others that establish broader protections for freelance workers and create new requirements for licensed cosmetologists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Looking Ahead to 5 Things That Will Shape the 2024 Election
description: Trials, a Kennedy and the economy are among the variables to consider.
content: It’s divisible by four. It’s a leap year. It’s a Summer Olympics year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Peter Magubane, 91, Who Fought Apartheid With His Camera, Is Dead
description: He documented the cruelties of white South African rule, and he was made to pay for it, enduring beatings and 586 consecutive days in solitary confinement.
content: Peter Magubane, a Black South African photographer whose images documenting the cruelties and violence of apartheid drew global acclaim but punishment at home, including beatings, imprisonment and 586 consecutive days of solitary confinement, died on Monday. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s Top Court Rejects Move to Limit It
description: Plus New Year’s offerings to the sea in Brazil.
content: Israel’s Supreme Court narrowly struck down a law proposed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that was meant to limit the court’s own powers. The momentous ruling, which was decided by a majority of eight judges to seven, could ignite a constitutional crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrey Henkin
title: Les McCann, Pianist, Singer and Soul Jazz Pioneer, Dies at 88
description: He released more than 50 albums but had his greatest commercial success with “Compared to What,” a recording that came together at the last minute in 1969.
content: Les McCann, a jazz pianist and vocalist who was an early progenitor of the bluesy, crowd-pleasing style that came to be known as soul jazz, and who, although he released more than 50 albums, was best known for a happenstance hit from 1969, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut
title: Putin Vows to Keep Up Bombardment After a Russian City Is Hit
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says his country will continue targeting Ukrainian cities in retaliation for a deadly attack on the city of Belgorod on Saturday.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia vowed on Monday to continue missile strikes on Ukrainian cities, in retaliation for what he called a “terror” attack on the Russian city of Belgorod last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Modern Swifties Have Transcended the Joke
description: Examining the linguistic persistence of Swiftian wordplay.
content: To be a Swiftie in the year 1729 might have meant that you fawned over the works of an Anglo-Irish writer named Jonathan, who would later be considered the “foremost prose satirist in the English language.” Centuries later, in the years leading up to 1989 (but still long before the release of “1989”), Swifties were jokes invoking Tom Swift, the hero of a series of pulp novels. The joke format, inspired by a writing quirk of the books, featured a dialogue tag tacked onto a spoken phrase so that the result was a groan-inducing one-liner. “‘Do you feel a draft?’ Tom asked coolly,” a Tom Swifty might go, or “‘You must be my host,’ Tom guessed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Young Love Meets Russian Repression. They Said ‘I Do’ in a Moscow Prison
description: She’s 18. He’s 23. He sent her a one-sentence letter through his prison’s electronic mail system: “Will you marry me?” They wed in a small room in a Moscow jail.
content: Nadezhda Shtovba did not wear a white dress to her wedding. There were no bridesmaids or groomsmen. She and her husband, Yegor, did not exchange wedding bands either — rings are banned in Butyrka prison.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Firecrackers and Ice: 5 Must-See Festivals in Asia This Winter
description: Catch a mountain trout on a frozen South Korean river, witness a fiery pelting of devotees in Taiwan or find your cold-weather bliss in a Japanese snow maze.
content: For many people, the joys of winter center on strapping on skis, snowshoes or skates and getting outdoors. Of course, that is no less true in many parts of Asia. But with climates ranging from the famously snowy Japanese island of Hokkaido to the tropical forests of Malaysia, the continent offers a wide variety of wintertime delights for travelers who are seeking something different from a day on the slopes. Fresh-caught mountain trout sashimi, anyone? Here are five festivals to check out this winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: I Spent New Year’s Eve Trying to Do the FAFSA. It Didn’t Go Well.
description: The new, simplified version of the college student aid form was supposed to become available in December. It was, kind of, for some people.
content: Since 2020, when Congress ordered up simplification of the federal financial aid system, the U.S. Department of Education has faced the complex task of actually making the changes to the ever-important formula for determining who gets what.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Making a Cooking Resolution? These 9 Recipes Will Get You Started.
description: Whether you want to eat less meat, bake more crowd-pleasing desserts or (finally) learn how to cook, here are some first steps for the new year.
content: If abiding by resolutions were as easy as setting them, perfection would be attainable and the self-improvement section of the bookstore would be cobweb city. Still, self-reflection can be a rewarding exercise at the beginning of a new year. What better place to start than in the kitchen, where you have to spend at least a little bit of time each day?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Lemony White Bean Soup With Turkey and Greens to Kick-Start the New Year
description: My five-star recipe freezes like a dream, too — make a double batch as insurance against those dragging, deep winter days.
content: Happy 2024! How did you ring it in? Were you in beast mode last night, shimmying from one party to the next? Or were you among those who welcomed the new year tranquilly from home? My household is Team Tranquil: a classic movie, a glass of Champagne and bed by 12:06. That means I’ve preserved enough pep today to cook something hearty and healthful to start the year — to set an intention, as they say, to widen my diet to include foods that aren’t cookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen and Jeffery C. Mays
title: To Avoid New York Rules, Hundreds of Migrants Dropped Off in New Jersey
description: Migrants, sent mostly from Texas, arrived at train stops outside New York City over the weekend to sidestep a new order limiting how they arrive.
content: Hundreds of migrants bound for New York City took a detour in New Jersey over the holiday weekend, in an apparent attempt to bypass a city order that seeks to limit the chaotic flow of arrivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Something to Whistle
description: Harry Zheng makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachael Scarborough King
title: Caregivers Helped Us Be a Family. Everyone Should Have That Option.
description: This year is a critical moment to make home care accessible to all Americans who need it.
content: My 7-year-old son, Carl, realized that it was Tuesday and asked why Robert was not coming to our house that day. Robert had been a caregiver for my husband, Ady Barkan, for more than five years, helping with Ady’s day-to-day activities as he became progressively paralyzed because of the neurodegenerative disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: Governor Defiance Tries to Usurp Washington’s Role
description: By taking over the federal role in immigration enforcement, Governor Abbott of Texas is welcoming a legal fight with the Biden administration.
content: In mid-December, just one day after Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas signed into law a radical new immigration bill, immigrant rights groups challenged it in court as ridiculously unconstitutional. The groups felt they had no choice, but they did exactly what Texas was counting on, because the point of the law isn’t simply how outrageous it is; it’s about the fight it will cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Emily Blunt Doesn’t Care if Her ‘Oppenheimer’ Character Is Likable
description: As the brilliant but flawed Kitty Oppenheimer, the actress plays a woman who had “extraordinary qualities, as well as ones that really let her down as a person.”
content: In “Oppenheimer,” the writer and director Christopher Nolan’s summer blockbuster biopic — three words that generally don’t go together — the character of Kitty Oppenheimer is effaced twice over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Is America on the Mend?
description: And will voters accept the good news?
content: Almost four years have passed since Covid-19 struck. In America, the pandemic killed well over a million people and left millions more with lingering health problems. Much of normal life came to a halt, partly because of official lockdowns but largely because fear of infection kept people home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: What’s Sapping Your Energy?
description: Your results will help you figure out how to have a more energetic 2024.
content: Your results will help you figure out how to have a more energetic 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Map: Earthquake Strikes Japan
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chevaz Clarke
title: Powerful Earthquake Hits Japan, Setting Off Tsunami Warnings
description: The epicenter of the quake was in Ishikawa Prefecture, along the west coast of Japan.
content: The epicenter of the quake was in Ishikawa Prefecture, along the west coast of Japan.
source.name: The New York Times
